div.l: Sauyng a child þat was of half ȝere age
In cradel it lay and was a ꝓpropre page
Þis wenche þikke and wel I growen was
With camois nose and eyen gray as glas
With buttokes brode and brestes round ⁊and hye
But right faire was hir here I wil not lye
The ꝑperson of the town for she was so faire
In pᵘurpos was to make hir his hayre
Both of his Catell ⁊and his messuagemessugemessuage
And stᵃraunge he made it of hir mariage
His pᵘurpos was to be stow hir hye
In to som worthy blode of Auncetrie
For holy chirches god moot ben dispendid
On holy chirche blode þat is descendit
Therfor he wold his holy blood honoure
Thow þat he holy chirche shold deuoure
Grete Soken hath þis Miller out of doute
With whete and malt of alle þe lond a bowte
And namely þer was a grete college
Men clepith þe soler halle at Cantabrige
Ther was hir whete and eke hir malt I gronde
And on a day hit happyt in a stound
Syke lay þe Manciple on a maladie
Men wenden wisly þat he shuld dye
For wiche þis Miller stale bothe mele ⁊and corn
A hundred tyme more þan byforne
For þer byforn he stal but curtesely
But now he was a thef outrageously
For wiche þe wardayn chid ⁊and made fare
But þerof set þe Miller nouȝt a tare
He crakkid bost and sware it was nouȝt so
Þen were þere ȝong scolers two
Þat dwellen in þe halle of wiche I seye
Testyf þei were ⁊and lusty for to play
And oonly for her myrth ⁊and reuerie
Vpon þe wardeyn bysili þei crye
To ȝeue hem leue but a litul stound
To go to mille and seyn her corn I ground
